overview_of_class: This course is an introductory seminar on history, theory, and criticism of video games. Individual works and movements will be studied through a framework that combines methods from media studies, game studies, and art history. We will situate the emerging medium of video games in a context that acknowledges multiple histories and discourses rather than defining video games as any single practice. We will distinguish between how video games extend traditions and ideas of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes or communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on historical and developing game practices and how they relate to other cultural contexts through analysis, discussion, writing, and playing.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. This course will introduce students to the field of game studies and the history of games. Students will demonstrate their awareness of these concepts through weekly reading assignments, written responses, and discussion leading.
2. This course will equip students with critical and theoretical frameworks for investigating interactive media artworks. Students demonstrate their grasp of frameworks through presentations and discussion on their selected research subject and method.
3. This course will develop critical writing skills. Students demonstrate their proficiency in this by researching and writing the final essay, as well as the frequent reading responses.

descriptions.value: Readings will be provided as pdf or web documents.

overview_of_class: There is an entire shadow history of media that associates new communication and information technologies with the occult, the absurd, the hysterical, the paranoid, and the otherwise "irrational." This course examines the "irrational" fringes of media history and practices, analyzing the larger significance of the irrational belief systems that attend the advent of electronic media.
